intro: Descurainia sophia, commonly known as tansy mustard, is an annual flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, four-petaled flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with hairy stems and alternate leaves that are lance-shaped and often glandular. Its flowers, which bloom from late spring to early summer, are yellow and attract various pollinators. The plant is often found in disturbed soils, such as roadsides and waste areas, and has been used in traditional herbal medicine.
